Award.AwardTitle: Free probability, polynomial families, and applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Free probability is a relatively young theory (started in the 1980s), with numerous powerful results and applications to the study of operator algebras, random matrices, and other fields. On the other hand, the study of polynomials goes back to the very beginnings of algebra, and orthogonal polynomials in particular are used throughout mathematics, physics, and engineering. Perhaps surprisingly, there are numerous relations between these two fields of study, through Fock space representations, martingale properties of polynomials, stochastic integrals, and special functions. Both fields have also developed numerous generalizations and extensions: operator-valued free probability theory and other non-commutative probability theories on one hand; and on the other, operator-valued orthogonal polynomials, polynomials of matrix argument, polynomials in multiple non-commuting variables, etc. This project will explore, through a series of specific problems, the objects mentioned above, emphasizing the connection between the two fields in the project title. It will also involve applications to other fields, notably random matrices.

It is a fundamental property of matrices that they may not commute. Since the beginning of quantum mechanics, probability theory of non-commuting objects has been an important field of research. In the 1980s, Voiculescu started the investigation of free probability theory, a theory of this type which also has numerous, sometimes spectacular, applications to operator algebras and the theory of random matrices (which itself plays an increasingly important role in physics and signal processing). On the other hand, polynomials are ubiquitous in mathematics, although polynomials in variables which do not commute are less familiar. This project will continue the study of the mutual interaction between these two subjects, applying techniques from each one to the study of the other. As part of the project, the PI will continue organizing seminars and conferences bringing together researchers and students from different fields. He will also continue his work with undergraduate students on research topics forming part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the key discoveries of 20th century physics is that both non-commutativity and randomness are inherent in nature. In fact the interplay between these two notions forms the basis of quantum mechanics. This project studied various results in Free Probability, involving randomness in the setting of maximal non-commutativity. Some phenomena are not affected by non-commutativity. For example, with John Williams we showed that certain types of limiting behavior of functions under composition (which is the most familiar setting for non-commutativity, i.e. the dependence on the order of factors) are identical to that of usual, commuting, random variables. With Octavio Arizmendi we showed that familiar relations between addition and multiplication of random variables still hold, at least partially, in the non-commutative realm. On the other hand, with J.C. Wang and Ping Zhong, we studied the phenomenon of superconvergence, first discovered by Bercovici and Voiculescu, which has no analog in the commutative realm. Going to even higher level of non-commutativity of operator-valued free probability, John Williams and I constructed families of non-commutative analytic functions on one hand, and non-commutative continued fractions on the other.

During the term of this project, I have continued to lead advanced courses and reading seminars, and supported visiting speakers in research seminars, to increase the exposure of local graduate students and young faculty to experts in their chosen fields; and organized several conferences, allowing graduate students and young faculty to communicate their research results. I have also worked on increasing the involvement of undergraduate students at Texas A&M University in mathematics research.
